what_if_analysis.conservative_return: Assume 10% CAGR: ₹100,000 grows to around ₹161,000 after 5 years.
what_if_analysis.moderate_return: Assume 14% CAGR (reasonable for aggressive stocks): ₹100,000 grows to around ₹191,000 after 5 years.
what_if_analysis.optimistic_return: Assume 18% CAGR (if bull market persists): ₹100,000 grows to approx ₹227,000 in 5 years.

summary: This portfolio is fully allocated to high-momentum, high-growth stocks spanning healthcare, financials, basic materials, industries, and consumer cyclicals. Sector spread mitigates specific risks, and aggressive picks are oriented towards strong historical returns. The objective is maximum capital appreciation, accepting volatility and sharp corrections for long-term higher returns.

risk_analysis.mild_crash: A 10% market dip would reduce portfolio to ₹90,000; recovery could be faster due to high-beta picks.
risk_analysis.moderate_crash: A 20% correction means ₹80,000 value; some sectors may lag in recovery, but pharma and consumer may buffer volatility.
risk_analysis.severe_crash: A 30% drawdown means ₹70,000; expect some stocks to suffer deeper individual falls.
risk_analysis.summary: This strategy accepts volatility in exchange for growth. Risk is higher than average, so periodic review and rebalancing are advised if fundamentals change.

education_tips.diversification_importance: Spreading investments across sectors (healthcare, finance, industry) limits portfolio damage from sector-specific shocks.
education_tips.long_term_perspective: Over 5 years, compounding works best. Ignore short-term dips; focus on company growth fundamentals.
education_tips.rebalancing_strategy: Review annually. If a stock underperforms or fundamentals worsen, rotate to stronger charts or emerging leaders.
education_tips.understanding_risk: High risk profiles may see larger swings. Do not panic on corrections; volatility is a feature, not a bug, in aggressive portfolios.
